Python Utilities Web Application - Folder Structure

Here's a recommended folder structure for your Python-based web application that provides various utilities:

Copy
Download
python-utilities-webapp/
│
├── app/                                # Main application package
│   ├── __init__.py                     # Package initialization
│   ├── main.py                         # Main application entry point
│   ├── config.py                       # Configuration settings
│   ├── static/                         # Static files (CSS, JS, images)
│   │   ├── css/
│   │   │   └── styles.css              # Main stylesheet
│   │   ├── js/
│   │   │   └── scripts.js              # Client-side JavaScript
│   │   └── images/                     # Application images
│   │
│   ├── templates/                      # HTML templates
│   │   ├── base.html                   # Base template
│   │   ├── index.html                  # Home page
│   │   ├── yaml_utility.html           # YAML formatter/validator
│   │   ├── pretty_files.html           # File prettifier
│   │   ├── confluence_template.html    # Confluence template utility
│   │   └── regex_tester.html           # Regex tester
│   │
│   ├── utilities/                      # Utility modules
│   │   ├── __init__.py
│   │   ├── yaml_utils.py               # YAML formatting/validation
│   │   ├── file_formatter.py           # File prettifying
│   │   ├── confluence_templates.py     # Template generation
│   │   ├── regex_tester.py             # Regex testing
│   │   └── common.py                   # Common utility functions
│   │
│   └── routes/                         # Application routes
│       ├── __init__.py
│       ├── main_routes.py              # Main routes
│       ├── yaml_routes.py              # YAML utility routes
│       ├── file_routes.py              # File prettifier routes
│       ├── template_routes.py          # Template routes
│       └── regex_routes.py             # Regex tester routes
│
├── tests/                              # Test files
│   ├── unit/
│   │   ├── test_yaml_utils.py
│   │   ├── test_file_formatter.py
│   │   ├── test_confluence_templates.py
│   │   └── test_regex_tester.py
│   └── integration/
│       └── test_routes.py
│
├── requirements.txt                    # Python dependencies
├── README.md                           # Project documentation
├── .gitignore                          # Git ignore file
├── Dockerfile                          # For containerization
└── setup.py                            # For package installation

Key Components Explanation:

  1. YAML Utility:

    • yaml_utils.py: Contains functions to validate and format YAML

    • yaml_routes.py: Handles web requests for YAML operations

    • yaml_utility.html: Frontend interface for YAML utility

  2. Pretty Files Utility:

    • file_formatter.py: Functions to prettify various file formats (JSON, XML, etc.)

    • file_routes.py: Web routes for file formatting

    • pretty_files.html: UI for file prettifying

  3. Confluence Template Utility:

    • confluence_templates.py: Generates templates that can be pasted into Confluence

    • template_routes.py: Handles template generation requests

    • confluence_template.html: Interface for template creation

  4. Regex Pattern Tester:

    • regex_tester.py: Core regex testing functionality

    • regex_routes.py: Web routes for regex testing

    • regex_tester.html: UI for testing regular expressions

Recommended Tech Stack:

  • Web Framework: Flask or FastAPI (lightweight and Pythonic)

  • YAML Processing: PyYAML library

  • Code Formatting: Python's built-in libraries or external like black for Python

  • Frontend: Simple HTML/CSS/JS (consider adding Bootstrap for styling)

  • Deployment: Can be containerized with Docker for easy deployment

This structure is modular and scalable, making it easy to add more utilities in the future. Each new utility would follow the same pattern:

  1. Add a new module in utilities/

  2. Add corresponding routes in routes/

  3. Create a template in templates/

Detailed Description of New Utilities:

    • Convert between JSON and XML formats

    • Beautify SQL queries with proper indentation

    • Generate version 1, 3, 4, and 5 UUIDs

    • Bulk generation option

    • Decode JSON Web Tokens with header and payload visualization

    • Generate hashes using MD5, SHA1, SHA256, etc.

    • HMAC generation with secret key

  6. Timestamp Converter

    • Convert between epoch timestamps and human-readable dates

    • Support for milliseconds, microseconds, and nanoseconds

    • Timezone conversion

  7. cURL to Code Converter

    • Convert cURL commands to Python (requests), JavaScript (fetch), etc.

    • Support for headers, cookies, and authentication

  8. Diff Tool

    • Compare two texts/files side by side

    • Highlight differences with color coding

  9. Mock Data Generator

    • Generate realistic test data (names, addresses, emails, etc.)

    • Customizable schemas for JSON/CSV output

  10. Color Code Converter

    • Convert between HEX, RGB, HSL, CMYK

    • Color palette generator

  11. Base64 Encoder/Decoder

    • Encode text/files to Base64

    • Decode Base64 back to original format

  12. URL Encoder/Decoder

    • Encode special characters in URLs

    • Decode encoded URLs

  13. QR Code Generator

    • Generate QR codes from text/URLs

    • Customizable size and error correction

  14. Lorem Ipsum Generator

    • Generate placeholder text in paragraphs, sentences, or words

    • Custom length options

  15. HTTP Status Codes Reference

    • Quick reference for all HTTP status codes

    • Search/filter functionality

Here's a complete solution that includes:

  1. A Python script to generate the folder structure

  2. A simple drawing tool using Python's tkinter (for drag-and-drop customization)

1. Script to Generate Folder Structure (create_structure.py)

python
Copy
Download
import os
from pathlib import Path

def create_structure(base_dir="python-utilities-webapp"):
    """Generates the complete folder structure for the utilities web app."""
    structure = {
        "app": {
            "__init__.py": "",
            "main.py": "# Flask/FastAPI app entry point",
            "config.py": "# App configuration",
            "static": {
                "css": {"styles.css": "/* Main CSS */"},
                "js": {"scripts.js": "// Client-side JS"},
                "images": {}
            },
            "templates": {
                "base.html": "<!DOCTYPE html>\n<html>...</html>",
                "index.html": "{% extends 'base.html' %}",
                "yaml_utility.html": "",
                "pretty_files.html": "",
                "confluence_template.html": "",
                "regex_tester.html": "",
                "json_xml_converter.html": "",
                "drawing_tool.html": "<!-- Canvas for drawing -->"
            },
            "utilities": {
                "__init__.py": "",
                "yaml_utils.py": "# YAML validation/formatting",
                "file_formatter.py": "# File prettifying",
                "confluence_templates.py": "# Confluence templates",
                "regex_tester.py": "# Regex testing",
                "drawing_utils.py": "# Drawing tool backend",
                "json_xml_converter.py": "",
                "sql_formatter.py": ""
            },
            "routes": {
                "__init__.py": "",
                "main_routes.py": "# Homepage routes",
                "yaml_routes.py": "",
                "drawing_routes.py": "# Handles drawing tool endpoints"
            }
        },
        "tests": {
            "unit": {
                "test_yaml_utils.py": "",
                "test_drawing_utils.py": ""
            },
            "integration": {}
        },
        "requirements.txt": "flask\npyyaml",
        "README.md": "# Python Utilities Web App",
        ".gitignore": "__pycache__/\n*.pyc",
        "Dockerfile": "FROM python:3.9\n..."
    }

    def build_path(path, contents):
        if isinstance(contents, dict):
            os.makedirs(path, exist_ok=True)
            for name, content in contents.items():
                build_path(os.path.join(path, name), content)
        else:
            with open(path, "w") as f:
                f.write(contents)

    build_path(base_dir, structure)
    print(f"✅ Folder structure created at: {Path(base_dir).resolve()}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    create_structure()

How to Run:

2. Simple Drawing Tool (app/utilities/drawing_utils.py)

python
Copy
Download
import tkinter as tk
from PIL import Image, ImageDraw

class DrawingTool:
    def __init__(self, width=800, height=600):
        self.root = tk.Tk()
        self.root.title("Python Drawing Tool")
        
        self.canvas = tk.Canvas(self.root, width=width, height=height, bg="white")
        self.canvas.pack()
        
        # Tools
        self.setup_toolbar()
        
        # Bind mouse events
        self.canvas.bind("<B1-Motion>", self.draw)
        self.canvas.bind("<ButtonRelease-1>", self.reset)
        
        self.last_x, self.last_y = None, None
        self.color = "black"
        self.line_width = 2
        self.drawing = False
        
    def setup_toolbar(self):
        toolbar = tk.Frame(self.root)
        toolbar.pack(fill=tk.X)
        
        colors = ["black", "red", "blue", "green", "yellow"]
        for color in colors:
            btn = tk.Button(toolbar, bg=color, width=3, command=lambda c=color: self.set_color(c))
            btn.pack(side=tk.LEFT, padx=2)
            
        tk.Scale(toolbar, from_=1, to=10, orient=tk.HORIZONTAL, 
                command=lambda val: self.set_line_width(val)).pack(side=tk.LEFT)
        
        tk.Button(toolbar, text="Clear", command=self.clear_canvas).pack(side=tk.LEFT)
        tk.Button(toolbar, text="Save", command=self.save_drawing).pack(side=tk.LEFT)
    
    def set_color(self, color):
        self.color = color
    
    def set_line_width(self, width):
        self.line_width = int(width)
    
    def draw(self, event):
        if self.last_x and self.last_y:
            self.canvas.create_line(
                self.last_x, self.last_y, event.x, event.y,
                width=self.line_width, fill=self.color, capstyle=tk.ROUND, smooth=True
            )
        self.last_x, self.last_y = event.x, event.y
    
    def reset(self, event):
        self.last_x, self.last_y = None, None
    
    def clear_canvas(self):
        self.canvas.delete("all")
    
    def save_drawing(self):
        filename = tk.filedialog.asksaveasfilename(defaultextension=".png")
        if filename:
            # Convert canvas to image
            self.canvas.postscript(file="tmp.eps", colormode="color")
            img = Image.open("tmp.eps")
            img.save(filename, "PNG")
            os.remove("tmp.eps")
    
    def run(self):
        self.root.mainloop()

# Example usage:
if __name__ == "__main__":
    app = DrawingTool()
    app.run()

Here's the complete code implementation for key utilities we've discussed, with testable examples for each:

1. YAML Validator/Formatter (app/utilities/yaml_utils.py)

python
Copy
Download
import yaml
from yaml import YAMLError

def validate_yaml(yaml_content):
    """Validate YAML content and return errors if any"""
    try:
        yaml.safe_load(yaml_content)
        return {"valid": True, "message": "Valid YAML"}
    except YAMLError as e:
        return {"valid": False, "message": str(e)}

def format_yaml(yaml_content):
    """Format ugly YAML into pretty version"""
    try:
        parsed = yaml.safe_load(yaml_content)
        return {
            "success": True,
            "formatted": yaml.dump(parsed, sort_keys=False, indent=2)
        }
    except YAMLError as e:
        return {"success": False, "error": str(e)}

# Test Example:
if __name__ == "__main__":
    test_yaml = """
    name: John Doe
    age: 30
    skills:
      - Python
      - YAML    # Bad indentation
    """
    
    print("Validation Result:", validate_yaml(test_yaml))
    print("Formatted YAML:", format_yaml(test_yaml)["formatted"])

2. JSON/XML Converter (app/utilities/json_xml_converter.py)

python
Copy
Download
import json
import xmltodict

def json_to_xml(json_str):
    """Convert JSON string to XML"""
    try:
        data = json.loads(json_str)
        return {"success": True, "xml": xmltodict.unparse(data, pretty=True)}
    except Exception as e:
        return {"success": False, "error": str(e)}

def xml_to_json(xml_str):
    """Convert XML string to JSON"""
    try:
        data = xmltodict.parse(xml_str)
        return {"success": True, "json": json.dumps(data, indent=2)}
    except Exception as e:
        return {"success": False, "error": str(e)}

# Test Example:
if __name__ == "__main__":
    sample_json = '{"person": {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}}'
    print("JSON to XML:", json_to_xml(sample_json)["xml"])
    
    sample_xml = '''
    <person>
        <name>Alice</name>
        <age>25</age>
    </person>
    '''
    print("XML to JSON:", xml_to_json(sample_xml)["json"])

3. Regex Tester (app/utilities/regex_tester.py)

python
Copy
Download
import re

def test_regex(pattern, text, flags=0):
    """Test regular expression against text"""
    try:
        matches = list(re.finditer(pattern, text, flags))
        groups = []
        for match in matches:
            groups.append({
                "full_match": match.group(0),
                "groups": match.groups(),
                "span": match.span()
            })
        return {
            "valid": True,
            "matches": groups,
            "match_count": len(matches)
        }
    except re.error as e:
        return {"valid": False, "error": str(e)}

# Test Example:
if __name__ == "__main__":
    result = test_regex(
        r"\b[A-Za-z0-9._%+-]+@[A-Za-z0-9.-]+\.[A-Z|a-z]{2,}\b",
        "Contact us at support@example.com or sales@company.org"
    )
    print("Regex Matches:", result)

4. SQL Formatter (app/utilities/sql_formatter.py)

python
Copy
Download
import sqlparse

def format_sql(sql, indent_width=2):
    """Format SQL query with proper indentation"""
    try:
        formatted = sqlparse.format(
            sql,
            reindent=True,
            indent_width=indent_width,
            keyword_case='upper'
        )
        return {"success": True, "formatted": formatted}
    except Exception as e:
        return {"success": False, "error": str(e)}

# Test Example:
if __name__ == "__main__":
    ugly_sql = "SELECT * FROM users WHERE id=1 ORDER BY name;"
    print("Formatted SQL:", format_sql(ugly_sql)["formatted"])

5. JWT Decoder (app/utilities/jwt_decoder.py)

python
Copy
Download
import jwt
import base64
import json
from datetime import datetime

def decode_jwt(token, verify_signature=False, secret=None):
    """Decode JWT token with optional signature verification"""
    try:
        decoded = jwt.decode(
            token,
            secret,
            algorithms=["HS256"],
            options={"verify_signature": verify_signature}
        )
        
        # Get header without verification
        header = jwt.get_unverified_header(token)
        
        return {
            "success": True,
            "header": header,
            "payload": decoded,
            "is_expired": check_jwt_expiry(decoded)
        }
    except Exception as e:
        return {"success": False, "error": str(e)}

def check_jwt_expiry(payload):
    """Check if JWT is expired"""
    if 'exp' in payload:
        return payload['exp'] < datetime.now().timestamp()
    return False

# Test Example:

    test_token = "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9.eyJzdWIiOiIxMjM0NTY3ODkwIiwibmFtZSI6IkpvaG4gRG9lIiwiaWF0IjoxNTE2MjM5MDIyfQ.SflKxwRJSMeKKF2QT4fwpMeJf36POk6yJV_adQssw5c"

6. Timestamp Converter (app/utilities/timestamp_converter.py)

from datetime import datetime

def timestamp_to_datetime(ts, unit='s'):
    """Convert timestamp to human-readable datetime"""
    try:
        if unit == 'ms':
            ts = float(ts) / 1000
        elif unit == 'µs':
            ts = float(ts) / 1_000_000
        elif unit == 'ns':
            ts = float(ts) / 1_000_000_000
            
        return {
            "success": True,
            "datetime": datetime.fromtimestamp(float(ts)).strftime('%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S'),
            "isoformat": datetime.fromtimestamp(float(ts)).isoformat()
        }
    except Exception as e:
        return {"success": False, "error": str(e)}

def datetime_to_timestamp(dt_str, unit='s'):
    """Convert datetime string to timestamp"""
    try:
        dt = datetime.strptime(dt_str, '%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S')
        ts = dt.timestamp()
        
        if unit == 'ms':
            ts = ts * 1000
        elif unit == 'µs':
            ts = ts * 1_000_000
        elif unit == 'ns':
            ts = ts * 1_000_000_000
            
        return {"success": True, "timestamp": ts}
    except Exception as e:
        return {"success": False, "error": str(e)}

# Test Example:
if __name__ == "__main__":
    print("Current timestamp:", datetime_to_timestamp("2023-01-01 12:00:00"))
    print("From timestamp:", timestamp_to_datetime("1672574400"))

7. cURL to Python Converter (app/utilities/curl_to_code.py)

python
Copy
Download
import re

def curl_to_python(curl_command):
    """Convert cURL command to Python requests code"""
    try:
        # Extract URL
        url_match = re.search(r"curl ['\"]([^'\"]+)['\"]", curl_command)
        if not url_match:
            url_match = re.search(r"curl (https?://\S+)", curl_command)
        if not url_match:
            return {"success": False, "error": "URL not found in cURL command"}
        
        url = url_match.group(1)
        
        # Extract headers
        headers = {}
        header_matches = re.finditer(r"-H ['\"]([^'\"]+)['\"]", curl_command)
        for match in header_matches:
            header = match.group(1).split(': ')
            headers[header[0]] = header[1]
        
        # Extract data
        data = None
        data_match = re.search(r"--data ['\"]([^'\"]+)['\"]", curl_command)
        if data_match:
            data = data_match.group(1)
        
        # Build Python code
        code = "import requests\n\n"
        code += f"url = '{url}'\n"
        
        if headers:
            code += "headers = {\n"
            for k, v in headers.items():
                code += f"    '{k}': '{v}',\n"
            code += "}\n\n"
        else:
            code += "headers = None\n\n"
        
        if data:
            code += f"data = '{data}'\n\n"
        
        code += "response = requests.request(\n"
        code += "    method='POST' if data else 'GET',\n"
        code += "    url=url,\n"
        code += "    headers=headers,\n"
        code += "    data=data\n"
        code += ")\n\n"
        code += "print(response.text)"
        
        return {"success": True, "code": code}
    except Exception as e:
        return {"success": False, "error": str(e)}

# Test Example:
if __name__ == "__main__":
    curl_example = """curl -X POST 'https://api.example.com/login' \
-H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
-H 'Authorization: Bearer token123' \
--data '{"username":"admin","password":"secret"}'"""
    
    print(curl_to_python(curl_example)["code"])

Based on your Docker command, I can see why your Kafka messages aren't persisting after a restart. Let me analyze the issue and provide a solution:

Problem Analysis

  1. No Persistent Storage: While you did mount a volume (-v /tmp/kraft-combined-logs:/tmp/kraft-combined-logs), the /tmp directory is typically cleared on system reboots in many Linux distributions.

  2. Ephemeral Storage: The logs are stored in /tmp/kraft-combined-logs inside the container, which is mapped to /tmp on your host machine - this is not a persistent location.

Solution: Proper Persistent Storage

Here's how to modify your Docker command for true persistence:

bash
Copy
Download
# Create a permanent directory for Kafka storage
mkdir -p ~/kafka_data/kraft-storage

# Run Kafka with persistent storage
docker run -d \
  --name kafka \
  --network host \
  -e KAFKA_ENABLE_KRAFT=yes \
  -e KAFKA_CFG_NODE_ID=1 \
  -e KAFKA_CFG_PROCESS_ROLES=controller,broker \
  -e KAFKA_CFG_CONTROLLER_QUORUM_VOTERS="1@${LOCAL_IP}:9093" \
  -e KAFKA_CFG_LISTENERS="PLAINTEXT://0.0.0.0:9092,CONTROLLER://0.0.0.0:9093" \
  -e KAFKA_CFG_ADVERTISED_LISTENERS="PLAINTEXT://${LOCAL_IP}:9092" \
  -e KAFKA_CFG_LOG_DIRS="/kafka/storage" \
  -e KAFKA_CFG_AUTO_CREATE_TOPICS_ENABLE="true" \
  -e KAFKA_ZOOKEEPER_CONNECT="" \
  -v ~/kafka_data/kraft-storage:/kafka/storage \
  --user root \
  --restart unless-stopped \
  --ulimit nofile=65536:65536 \
  apache/kafka:3.7.0 \
  sh -c "
    echo 'Formatting storage with uid: \$(id -u) gid: \$(id -g)';
    /opt/kafka/bin/kafka-storage.sh format -t \$(\
      /opt/kafka/bin/kafka-storage.sh random-uuid\
    ) -c /opt/kafka/config/kraft/server.properties --ignore-formatted;
    echo 'Starting Kafka server...';
    exec /opt/kafka/bin/kafka-server-start.sh /opt/kafka/config/kraft/server.properties
  "

Key Changes Made:

  1. Persistent Directory:

    • Created ~/kafka_data/kraft-storage in your home directory (won't be cleared on reboots)

    • Changed volume mount to -v ~/kafka_data/kraft-storage:/kafka/storage

  2. Updated LOG_DIRS:

    • Changed from /tmp/kraft-combined-logs to /kafka/storage

Verification Steps:

  1. Check if data persists after restart:

bash
Copy
Download
docker restart kafka
docker exec -it kafka ls -la /kafka/storage

  1. Check messages in a topic:

bash
Copy
Download
docker exec -it kafka /opt/kafka/bin/kafka-console-consumer.sh \
  --bootstrap-server localhost:9092 \
  --topic your-topic \
  --from-beginning

Additional Recommendations:

  1. For Production:

    • Use a dedicated storage location (e.g., /var/lib/kafka)

    • Consider using Docker volumes instead of host mounts

    • Implement proper backup procedures

  2. If you need to recover your existing setup:

bash
Copy
Download
# Stop and remove old container
docker stop kafka && docker rm kafka

# Copy existing data to new location (if needed)
cp -r /tmp/kraft-combined-logs ~/kafka_data/kraft-storage

# Then run the new container with persistent storage

This configuration will ensure your Kafka messages persist across container restarts and host reboots. The data will now be stored in ~/kafka_data/kraft-storage on your host machine.

2. LDAP User Tracking Integration

python
Copy
Download
# app/utilities/usage_tracker.py
from datetime import datetime
from flask import request, g
import ldap
from functools import wraps

def init_ldap(app):
    app.config['LDAP_SERVER'] = 'ldap://your-server'
    app.config['LDAP_BASE_DN'] = 'dc=example,dc=com'

def track_usage(utility_name):
    def decorator(f):
        @wraps(f)
        def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
            start_time = datetime.utcnow()
            
            # LDAP user identification
            if 'Authorization' in request.headers:
                user = authenticate_ldap(request.headers['Authorization'])
            else:
                user = "anonymous"
            
            # Execute utility
            result = f(*args, **kwargs)
            
            # Log usage
            duration = (datetime.utcnow() - start_time).total_seconds()
            log_usage(user, utility_name, duration)
            
            return result
        return wrapper
    return decorator

def authenticate_ldap(token):
    try:
        conn = ldap.initialize(app.config['LDAP_SERVER'])
        conn.simple_bind_s(f"uid={token},ou=users,{app.config['LDAP_BASE_DN']}", "")
        return token
    except ldap.LDAPError:
        return "unauthorized"

def log_usage(username, utility, duration):
    # Store in database (SQLite example)
    from app import db
    db.execute(
        "INSERT INTO usage_logs (username, utility, duration, timestamp) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?)",
        (username, utility, duration, datetime.utcnow())
    )
    db.commit()

3. Dashboard with Metrics

python
Copy
Download
# app/routes/dashboard_routes.py
from flask import Blueprint, render_template
from collections import Counter
from datetime import datetime, timedelta

dashboard_bp = Blueprint('dashboard', __name__)

@dashboard_bp.route('/dashboard')
def usage_dashboard():
    # Get usage data
    logs = query_db("SELECT * FROM usage_logs WHERE timestamp > ?", 
                   (datetime.utcnow() - timedelta(days=30),))
    
    # Process metrics
    metrics = {
        'total_uses': len(logs),
        'active_users': len({log['username'] for log in logs}),
        'popular_utilities': Counter(log['utility'] for log in logs).most_common(5),
        'avg_duration': sum(log['duration'] for log in logs) / len(logs) if logs else 0,
        'usage_trend': get_usage_trend(logs)
    }
    
    return render_template('dashboard.html', metrics=metrics)

def get_usage_trend(logs):
    # Group by day
    trend = {}
    for log in logs:
        day = log['timestamp'].strftime('%Y-%m-%d')
        trend[day] = trend.get(day, 0) + 1
    return sorted(trend.items())

Here's a complete implementation to track usage in SQLite and display rich analytics on the dashboard:

1. Enhanced Database Setup (app/database.py)

python
Copy
Download
import sqlite3
from datetime import datetime
from contextlib import contextmanager

DATABASE = 'usage.db'

def init_db():
    with db_connection() as conn:
        conn.execute('''
        CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS usage_history (
            id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT,
            username TEXT NOT NULL,
            utility_name TEXT NOT NULL,
            duration_sec REAL NOT NULL,
            timestamp DATETIME NOT NULL,
            params TEXT
        )''')
        conn.execute('''
        CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS user_favorites (
            username TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
            favorite_utility TEXT,
            last_used DATETIME
        )''')
        conn.commit()

@contextmanager
def db_connection():
    conn = sqlite3.connect(DATABASE)
    conn.row_factory = sqlite3.Row  # Enable column access by name
    try:
        yield conn
    finally:
        conn.close()

def log_usage(username, utility_name, duration, params=None):
    with db_connection() as conn:
        conn.execute('''
        INSERT INTO usage_history 
        (username, utility_name, duration_sec, timestamp, params)
        VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?)
        ''', (username, utility_name, duration, datetime.now(), str(params)))
        
        # Update favorites
        conn.execute('''
        INSERT OR REPLACE INTO user_favorites 
        (username, favorite_utility, last_used)
        VALUES (?, ?, ?)
        ''', (username, utility_name, datetime.now()))
        conn.commit()

2. Usage Tracking Decorator (app/utilities/tracking.py)

python
Copy
Download
from functools import wraps
from time import time
from flask import request, g
from app.database import log_usage

def track_usage(utility_name):
    def decorator(f):
        @wraps(f)
        def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
            start_time = time()
            
            # Get user identity (extend with your auth system)
            username = getattr(g, 'username', 'anonymous')
            
            # Execute the utility function
            result = f(*args, **kwargs)
            
            # Log usage metrics
            duration = time() - start_time
            log_usage(
                username=username,
                utility_name=utility_name,
                duration=duration,
                params=request.get_json() if request.is_json else None
            )
            
            return result
        return wrapper
    return decorator

3. Enhanced Dashboard Routes (app/routes/dashboard.py)

python
Copy
Download
from flask import Blueprint, render_template
from app.database import db_connection
from datetime import datetime, timedelta
from collections import Counter

dashboard_bp = Blueprint('dashboard', __name__)

@dashboard_bp.route('/dashboard')
def show_dashboard():
    with db_connection() as conn:
        # Basic metrics
        total_uses = conn.execute('SELECT COUNT(*) FROM usage_history').fetchone()[0]
        active_users = conn.execute('SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT username) FROM usage_history').fetchone()[0]
        
        # Popular utilities
        popular_utils = conn.execute('''
            SELECT utility_name, COUNT(*) as use_count 
            FROM usage_history 
            GROUP BY utility_name 
            ORDER BY use_count DESC 
            LIMIT 5
        ''').fetchall()
        
        # Usage trend (last 30 days)
        trend_data = conn.execute('''
            SELECT date(timestamp) as day, COUNT(*) as uses
            FROM usage_history
            WHERE timestamp > ?
            GROUP BY day
            ORDER BY day
        ''', (datetime.now() - timedelta(days=30),)).fetchall()
        
        # User favorites
        user_favorites = conn.execute('''
            SELECT favorite_utility, COUNT(*) as fav_count
            FROM user_favorites
            GROUP BY favorite_utility
            ORDER BY fav_count DESC
            LIMIT 5
        ''').fetchall()
        
        # Recent activity
        recent_activity = conn.execute('''
            SELECT username, utility_name, timestamp
            FROM usage_history
            ORDER BY timestamp DESC
            LIMIT 10
        ''').fetchall()
    
    return render_template('dashboard.html',
        total_uses=total_uses,
        active_users=active_users,
        popular_utils=popular_utils,
        trend_data=trend_data,
        user_favorites=user_favorites,
        recent_activity=recent_activity
    )

@dashboard_bp.route('/api/usage-report')
def generate_usage_report():
    # Could return CSV/JSON for export
    pass

  1. Run init_db() at application startup

  2. Decorate all utility functions with @track_usage()

  3. Access dashboard at /dashboard

For additional utilities, simply:

  1. Create the new utility function

  2. Add the tracking decorator

  3. It will automatically appear in analytics

2. Real-Time Monitoring Middleware (app/monitoring.py)

python
Copy
Download
import psutil
from threading import Timer
from datetime import datetime
from app.database import db_connection

def start_monitoring(interval=60):
    """Start periodic system monitoring"""
    def monitor():
        with db_connection() as conn:
            # Record system metrics
            conn.execute('''
            INSERT INTO system_metrics 
            (timestamp, active_users, cpu_load, memory_usage)
            VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?)
            ''', (
                datetime.now(),
                get_active_users(),
                psutil.cpu_percent(),
                psutil.virtual_memory().percent
            ))
            
            # Check for resource crunches
            check_resource_limits()
            
        # Schedule next run
        Timer(interval, monitor).start()
    
    monitor()

def check_resource_limits():
    with db_connection() as conn:
        # Disable utilities at 90% memory or CPU
        if (psutil.virtual_memory().percent > 90 or 
            psutil.cpu_percent() > 90):
            conn.execute('''
            UPDATE utility_status 
            SET disabled = TRUE
            WHERE current_users > max_concurrent * 0.8
            ''')
            conn.commit()

def get_active_users():
    with db_connection() as conn:
        return conn.execute('''
        SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT username) 
        FROM usage_history 
        WHERE timestamp > datetime('now', '-5 minutes')
        ''').fetchone()[0]

3. Enhanced Usage Tracking with Capacity Checks

python
Copy
Download
# app/utilities/tracking.py
from flask import jsonify
from app.database import db_connection

def track_usage(utility_name):
    def decorator(f):
        @wraps(f)
        def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
            # Check capacity before proceeding
            with db_connection() as conn:
                status = conn.execute('''
                SELECT current_users, max_concurrent, disabled 
                FROM utility_status 
                WHERE utility_name = ?
                ''', (utility_name,)).fetchone()
                
                if status['disabled']:
                    return jsonify({
                        'error': 'Service temporarily unavailable due to high load',
                        'status': 503
                    }), 503
                    
                if status['current_users'] >= status['max_concurrent']:
                    return jsonify({
                        'error': f'Maximum concurrent users ({status["max_concurrent"]}) reached',
                        'suggested_wait': 60  # seconds
                    }), 429
                
                # Increment user count
                conn.execute('''
                UPDATE utility_status 
                SET current_users = current_users + 1 
                WHERE utility_name = ?
                ''', (utility_name,))
                conn.commit()
            
            try:
                # Original function execution
                return f(*args, **kwargs)
            finally:
                # Decrement user count
                with db_connection() as conn:
                    conn.execute('''
                    UPDATE utility_status 
                    SET current_users = current_users - 1 
                    WHERE utility_name = ?
                    ''', (utility_name,))
                    conn.commit()
        return wrapper
    return decorator

4. Enhanced Dashboard Metrics (app/routes/dashboard.py)

python

@dashboard_bp.route('/user/<username>')
def user_metrics(username):
    with db_connection() as conn:
        # User-specific metrics
        user_stats = conn.execute('''
        SELECT 
            COUNT(*) as total_uses,
            SUM(duration_sec) as total_time,
            COUNT(DISTINCT utility_name) as utilities_used
        FROM usage_history 
        WHERE username = ?
        ''', (username,)).fetchone()
        
        favorite_utility = conn.execute('''
        SELECT favorite_utility 
        FROM user_favorites 
        WHERE username = ?
        ''', (username,)).fetchone()
        
        usage_trend = conn.execute('''
        SELECT date(timestamp) as day, COUNT(*) as uses
        FROM usage_history
        WHERE username = ?
        GROUP BY day
        ORDER BY day DESC
        LIMIT 7
        ''', (username,)).fetchall()
        
        # System status
        system_status = conn.execute('''
        SELECT 
            SUM(current_users) as active_users,
            AVG(cpu_load) as avg_cpu,
            AVG(memory_usage) as avg_mem
        FROM system_metrics
        WHERE timestamp > datetime('now', '-1 hour')
        ''').fetchone()
        
        utility_status = conn.execute('''
        SELECT utility_name, current_users, max_concurrent, disabled
        FROM utility_status
        ''').fetchall()
    
    return render_template('user_metrics.html',
        username=username,
        user_stats=user_stats,
        favorite_utility=favorite_utility,
        usage_trend=usage_trend,
        system_status=system_status,
        utility_status=utility_status
    )

Here's a comprehensive Skill Matrix Utility implementation that allows users to update their skills and provides manager-level analytics:

1. Database Schema Updates (app/database.py)

python
Copy
Download
def init_db():
    with db_connection() as conn:
        # Add skills tables
        conn.execute('''
        CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS skills (
            skill_id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT,
            skill_name TEXT UNIQUE,
            category TEXT,
            description TEXT
        )''')
        
        conn.execute('''
        CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS user_skills (
            user_id TEXT,
            skill_id INTEGER,
            proficiency INTEGER CHECK(proficiency BETWEEN 1 AND 5),
            last_updated DATETIME,
            PRIMARY KEY (user_id, skill_id),
            FOREIGN KEY (skill_id) REFERENCES skills(skill_id)
        )''')
        
        # Insert default skills if empty
        if not conn.execute('SELECT 1 FROM skills LIMIT 1').fetchone():
            conn.executemany('''
            INSERT INTO skills (skill_name, category) 
            VALUES (?, ?)''', [
                ('Python', 'Programming'),
                ('Java', 'Programming'),
                ('SQL', 'Database'),
                ('Docker', 'DevOps'),
                ('AWS', 'Cloud')
            ])
        conn.commit()

2. Skill Matrix Routes (app/routes/skills.py)

python
Copy
Download
from flask import Blueprint, request, jsonify
from app.database import db_connection
from datetime import datetime

skills_bp = Blueprint('skills', __name__)

@skills_bp.route('/skills/update', methods=['POST'])
def update_skills():
    data = request.get_json()
    username = data['username']
    updates = data['skills']  # Format: [{"skill_id":1, "proficiency":3},...]
    
    with db_connection() as conn:
        # Update user skills
        for update in updates:
            conn.execute('''
            INSERT OR REPLACE INTO user_skills 
            (user_id, skill_id, proficiency, last_updated)
            VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?)
            ''', (username, update['skill_id'], update['proficiency'], datetime.now()))
        
        conn.commit()
    
    return jsonify({"status": "success"})

@skills_bp.route('/skills/list')
def list_skills():
    with db_connection() as conn:
        skills = conn.execute('''
        SELECT skill_id, skill_name, category 
        FROM skills 
        ORDER BY category, skill_name
        ''').fetchall()
        return jsonify([dict(skill) for skill in skills])

@skills_bp.route('/skills/user/<username>')
def get_user_skills(username):
    with db_connection() as conn:
        skills = conn.execute('''
        SELECT s.skill_id, s.skill_name, s.category, 
               us.proficiency, us.last_updated
        FROM skills s
        LEFT JOIN user_skills us ON s.skill_id = us.skill_id AND us.user_id = ?
        ORDER BY s.category, s.skill_name
        ''', (username,)).fetchall()
        return jsonify([dict(skill) for skill in skills])

@skills_bp.route('/skills/metrics')
def skill_metrics():
    with db_connection() as conn:
        # Skill distribution
        distribution = conn.execute('''
        SELECT s.skill_name, COUNT(us.user_id) as user_count,
               AVG(us.proficiency) as avg_proficiency
        FROM skills s
        LEFT JOIN user_skills us ON s.skill_id = us.skill_id
        GROUP BY s.skill_name
        ''').fetchall()
        
        # Skill gaps (proficiency < 3)
        gaps = conn.execute('''
        SELECT s.skill_name, COUNT(*) as gap_count
        FROM user_skills us
        JOIN skills s ON us.skill_id = s.skill_id
        WHERE us.proficiency < 3
        GROUP BY s.skill_name
        ORDER BY gap_count DESC
        ''').fetchall()
        
        # Top proficient users
        top_users = conn.execute('''
        SELECT us.user_id, COUNT(*) as expert_skills
        FROM user_skills us
        WHERE us.proficiency >= 4
        GROUP BY us.user_id
        ORDER BY expert_skills DESC
        LIMIT 5
        ''').fetchall()
        
        return jsonify({
            "distribution": [dict(row) for row in distribution],
            "skill_gaps": [dict(row) for row in gaps],
            "top_users": [dict(row) for row in top_users]
        })

<script>
// Save skills
document.getElementById('saveSkills').addEventListener('click', async () => {
    const updates = [];
    document.querySelectorAll('.proficiency-select').forEach(select => {
        const newValue = parseInt(select.value);
        const oldValue = parseInt(select.dataset.oldValue || '0');
        if (newValue !== oldValue) {
            updates.push({
                skill_id: parseInt(select.dataset.skillId),
                proficiency: newValue
            });
        }
    });
    
    const response = await fetch('/skills/update', {
        method: 'POST',
        headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
        body: JSON.stringify({
            username: "{{ current_user }}",
            skills: updates
        })
    });
    
    if (response.ok) {
        alert('Skills updated successfully!');
        location.reload();
    }
});

from flask import Flask
from flask_sqlalchemy import SQLAlchemy
from config import Config

db = SQLAlchemy()

def create_app():
    app = Flask(__name__)
    app.config.from_object(Config)
    
    db.init_app(app)
    
    from app.routes import skill_routes, training_routes
    app.register_blueprint(skill_routes.bp)
    app.register_blueprint(training_routes.bp)

app/database.py

python
Copy
Download
from . import db
from datetime import datetime

class Skill(db.Model):
    __tablename__ = 'skills'
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    name = db.Column(db.String(80), unique=True)
    category = db.Column(db.String(50))
    
class UserSkill(db.Model):
    __tablename__ = 'user_skills'
    user_id = db.Column(db.String(50), primary_key=True)
    skill_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('skills.id'), primary_key=True)
    proficiency = db.Column(db.Integer)
    last_validated = db.Column(db.DateTime)
    cert_url = db.Column(db.String(255))

class TrainingResource(db.Model):
    __tablename__ = 'training_resources'
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    skill_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('skills.id'))
    title = db.Column(db.String(100))
    url = db.Column(db.String(255))
    difficulty = db.Column(db.Integer)  # 1-5

app/services/recommendation_service.py

python
Copy
Download
from ..models import UserSkill, TrainingResource

def get_recommendations(user_id):
    # Get skills needing improvement (proficiency < 3)
    low_skills = UserSkill.query.filter_by(
        user_id=user_id,
        proficiency < 3
    ).all()
    
    recommendations = []
    for skill in low_skills:
        resources = TrainingResource.query.filter_by(
            skill_id=skill.skill_id,
            difficulty <= 3  # Only recommend beginner/intermediate
        ).order_by(TrainingResource.difficulty).limit(3).all()
        
        recommendations.extend(resources)
    
    return recommendations

import requests
from datetime import datetime

def validate_certification(cert_url):
    """Check if certification URL is valid"""
    try:
        response = requests.head(cert_url)
        if response.status_code == 200:
            return True, "Valid certification"
        return False, "Certificate not found"
    except:
        return False, "Invalid URL"

def approve_skill(user_id, skill_id, cert_url=None):
    """Manager approval flow"""
    if cert_url:
        is_valid, message = validate_certification(cert_url)
        if not is_valid:
            return False, message
    
    # Update validation timestamp
    skill = UserSkill.query.filter_by(
        user_id=user_id,
        skill_id=skill_id
    ).first()
    
    if skill:
        skill.last_validated = datetime.utcnow()
        skill.cert_url = cert_url
        db.session.commit()
        return True, "Skill validated"
    
    return False, "Skill not found"

app/routes/skill_routes.py

python
Copy
Download
from flask import Blueprint, jsonify, request
from ..services import validation_service
from ..models import Skill, UserSkill

bp = Blueprint('skills', __name__)

@bp.route('/skills', methods=['GET'])
def list_skills():
    skills = Skill.query.all()
    return jsonify([{
        'id': s.id,
        'name': s.name,
        'category': s.category
    } for s in skills])

@bp.route('/skills/validate', methods=['POST'])
def validate_skill():
    data = request.json
    success, message = validation_service.approve_skill(
        data['user_id'],
        data['skill_id'],
        data.get('cert_url')
    )
    return jsonify({'success': success, 'message': message})

        'title': r.title,
        'url': r.url,
        'difficulty': r.difficulty
    } for r in recs])

3. Setup Script (setup.py)

python
Copy
Download
import os
from app import create_app, db
from app.models import Skill, TrainingResource

def init_db():
    app = create_app()
    with app.app_context():
        db.create_all()
        
        # Seed initial data
        if not Skill.query.first():
            skills = [
                Skill(name='Python', category='Programming'),
                Skill(name='Java', category='Programming'),
                Skill(name='Docker', category='DevOps')
            ]
            db.session.add_all(skills)
            
            trainings = [
                TrainingResource(
                    skill_id=1,
                    title='Python for Beginners',
                    url='https://example.com/python',
                    difficulty=1
                )
            ]
            db.session.add_all(trainings)
            db.session.commit()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    init_db()
    print("Database initialized successfully!")

1. Performance Optimizations

app/__init__.py (Updated)

python
Copy
Download
from flask import Flask
from flask_sqlalchemy import SQLAlchemy
from flask_caching import Cache
from config import Config

db = SQLAlchemy()
cache = Cache(config={'CACHE_TYPE': 'SimpleCache'})

def create_app():
    app = Flask(__name__)
    app.config.from_object(Config)
    
    # Database and cache setup
    db.init_app(app)
    cache.init_app(app)
    
    # Connection pooling
    app.config['SQLALCHEMY_ENGINE_OPTIONS'] = {
        'pool_size': 20,
        'max_overflow': 100,
        'pool_timeout': 30,
        'pool_recycle': 3600
    }
    
    # Register blueprints
    from app.routes import skill_routes, training_routes
    app.register_blueprint(skill_routes.bp)
    app.register_blueprint(training_routes.bp)
    
    return app

5. Load-Tested Route Example

app/routes/skill_routes.py (Updated)

python
Copy
Download
from flask import Blueprint, jsonify
from ..models import Skill
from .. import db, cache

bp = Blueprint('skills', __name__)

@bp.route('/skills/metrics')
@cache.cached(timeout=60)
def skill_metrics():
    # Use raw SQL for complex analytics
    metrics = db.session.execute("""
        SELECT 
            s.name,
            COUNT(us.user_id) as user_count,
            AVG(us.proficiency) as avg_prof
        FROM skills s
        LEFT JOIN user_skills us ON s.id = us.skill_id
        GROUP BY s.name
        ORDER BY user_count DESC
    """).fetchall()
    
    return jsonify([dict(row) for row in metrics])

4. Nginx Configuration (/etc/nginx/sites-available/skillmatrix)

nginx
Copy
Download
upstream app_server {
    server 127.0.0.1:8000 fail_timeout=0;
}

server {
    listen 80;
    server_name your-vm-ip-or-domain;

    client_max_body_size 4G;
    keepalive_timeout 5;

    location / {
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
        proxy_set_header Host $http_host;
        proxy_redirect off;
        
        if (!-f $request_filename) {
            proxy_pass http://app_server;
            break;
        }
    }

    location /static/ {
        alias /app/static/;
        expires 30d;
    }

    error_page 500 502 503 504 /500.html;
}
